Supersonic Interceptor Minimum Time Climb¶

This example is based on the A/C Min Time to Climb example given in chapter 4 of Bryson[@bryson1999dynamic]. It finds the angle-of-attack history required to accelerate a supersonic interceptor from near ground level, Mach 0.4 to an altitude of 20 km and Mach 1.0.

The vehicle dynamics are given by

(51)¶\[\begin{align} \frac{dv}{dt} &= \frac{T}{m} \cos \alpha - \frac{D}{m} - g \sin \gamma \\ \frac{d\gamma}{dt} &= \frac{T}{m v} \sin \alpha + \frac{L}{m v} - \frac{g \cos \gamma}{v} \\ \frac{dh}{dt} &= v \sin \gamma \\ \frac{dr}{dt} &= v \cos \gamma \\ \frac{dm}{dt} &= - \frac{T}{g I_{sp}} \end{align}\]

The initial conditions are

(52)¶\[\begin{align} r_0 &= 0 \rm{\,m} \\ h_0 &= 100 \rm{\,m} \\ v_0 &= 135.964 \rm{\,m/s} \\ \gamma_0 &= 0 \rm{\,deg} \\ m_0 &= 19030.468 \rm{\,kg} \end{align}\]

and the final conditions are

(53)¶\[\begin{align} h_f &= 20000 \rm{\,m} \\ M_f &= 1.0 \\ \gamma_0 &= 0 \rm{\,deg} \end{align}\]

The ODE System: min_time_climb_ode.py¶

The top level ODE definition is a Group that connects several subsystems.

=== “min_time_climb.min_time_climb_ode.py”
